"I'm in despair!" so said Itoshiki Nozomu (Mr. despair).
To begin with, the anime have no story. Evey episode have his own story. 
Itoshiki is a teacher in highschool. He is the class teacher of a class full of girls (there are some boys though..) and every girl have her own wierd habits. 
Itoshiki is getting despair from things that usually make one lough. he is teaching his students that life not promising and only lead to despair. On the contrary, Kafuka Fuura, one of his students, who always sees everything in the most optemistic way, showing him that life not so bad.
in every episode Itoshikigetting depressed and so on.\n
I LOVE this anime and especially it's music.

Sayonara Zetsubou Sensei - 9/10
I really really want to give this show an 8/10 because that's what it really deserves, but because i love the op song and the soundtrack in general so i'll keep it a 9.
So, SZS's main cast consists of Itoshiki Sensei and 12 schoolgirls and one teacher. All the characters have some kind of mental issue or problem/characteristic which is the main source of humor in this show. For example the Hikikimori girl who never talks and whenever Itoshiki sees her, he just walks off, Kafuka who is overly postivie and childish (she said her Father was trying to become higherusing a rope and a tree, just like Itoshiki when he was trying to hang himself), or maybe the Stalker girl Mayoi who is pretty much in every scene just staring at Itoshiki and sitting under his desk and such. Those problems are exploited to different situations and are mocked to no end, maybe taking a stereotype character isn't exactly the most creative way but the way SZS makes use of it truly allows for some funny situations.\n
One thing i must say as a warning, half the humor comes in writing on the boards, just text slides and more, just what you'd expect from SHAFT, but here it's to a whole new level, aswell as considering the show's relatively low budget, which actually suits it very well and makes it feel less serious.\n
Also some humor (especially last episode) mocks Japan and to understand it you have to have some understanding of Japanese culture and Japanese people's mindset, also one of the girls is a typical "gajin" so if you're offended by Nips taking a piss at way a typical foreigner girl acts (to be precise like a whore and a source of pantyshots who starts sueing everyone when she gets the chance) and there's even a joke about "fanservice for Russian otaku" with her being blonde and blue-eyed, so if you're offended by this show, go fuck yourself and watch some mediocre comedy like Oreimo or something.\n
There isn't really much to this show if you don't like the characters, or take them seriously. The art reminds me that of FLCL, thus lack of 3DCG and complicated backgrounds, but since this is comedy there's not much animation and more text and dialogue, but if you watch SHAFT's adaptions like Monogatari then you're used to that anyway.\n
Also this show isn't a harem, really, it has a female cast because.... no real reason as far as i could tell, aside from making it more fun to watch?\n
I guess the first half of the show is much better, since it dedicates a character an episode, but the latter half really just reuses the same jokes in different context and creates some character unrelated comedy which still works well.\n
I really hope there's more in the 2nd season, because just repeating the same thing won't exactly work out.

“A pessimist sees the difficulty in every opportunity; an optimist sees the opportunity in every difficulty.” 
― Winston S. Churchill
I find that quote to be a very fitting mindset to have while watching this series.
Sayonara Zetsubou Sensei is not your average gag/satirical anime. What should be dark is funny and even when we think the world is as dark as the bottom of the ocean, this series somehow manages to throw in a shred of light and bring about laughter in such dark topics.  
To be honest, I enjoyed this show because I am a pessimist my self much like the main character (wellnot to that extreme). Many of the dialogue or jokes within the series are actually social commentary. And if you are a big anime/manga fan and are decently informed about social issues, politics and current events and the like, this should be quite enjoyable for you. \n\n
Yes there are cheesy moments in the show but I never felt at any point that the creator of this show tried to take advantage of the audience by presenting cheap fan service shots or tried to forcibly invoke laughter. \n\n
Visually, Sayonara Zetsubou Sensei is moderate at best. Not too many flashy colors, not to dull either, a good balance and I'd say the animation is definitely easy on the eyes. The artwork on the still frames are very vibrant and enjoyable too. \n\n
The audio is just awesome. The OP and ED  snippets are a little crazier than most of the animation in show but it really gets your attention. The voicing in this series isn't half bad either. I don't know too much about Japanese seiyuu but for the purposes of this show, they get the job more than done.\n\n
To wrap things up, this anime is a must watch if you really enjoy dark humor and satire. A little psychotic perhaps to spice things up, and definitely a little more psychological than the usual brainless cheap laugh inducing fan service laden gag anime. It is a must watch. \n
Overall experience and after thoughts: 9/10

First time I watched this. I thought it was pretty funny, but at the same time. Boring as hell since nothing was really happening.

Story 7
The story is about the teacher (Nozomu Itoshiki) and all hisnegative aspects of life. Leading a class of students with a Girl (Kafuka Fuura) that's the complete opposite of him.

He constantly tries to take his own life when he is in despair, but his students in his class always prevent him. He always tries to teach them his own personal aspects of life, leaving the students in desperation but then at the same time, proves him wrong.


The story itself its just him and his class. Some students are unique and kinda different in a weird way. Also his associate is always a shown in a perverted way.


The story was the only that kept me almost going asleep after seeing 1 episode. I wanted to see more but at the same time, i got bored since the story is not developing. What was developing was the relationships. More I will not say to spoil anything.

 If you love the humour in this Series, you will love the Series. I think the humour is pretty funny, sometimes I literally had to pause the video until i stopped laughing. And sometimes, it was nothing special.

A very good comedy, only lacks a more deep story. But I'm sure this will be shown in the sequels.


Art 8

The art itself is simple but beautiful and well made. It kinda fits with the comedy feeling. At first, you could think this series will be bad since the art seems so plain and simple. But it's well done and much come in to play with the comedy. 

It is great, could have been better with a touch of more regular drawings.

I felt the hair on everyone was WAY to simple and almost everyone is blacked hair and the hair itself is not very creatively done. 

If you really cant get used to the art, it will effect your enjoyment experience. 


Sound 10

Music is amazing. The tracks fit perfectly in regard to what is happening. It's very creatively done and fit so well. It's indescribable. The Teacher is also voiced by Kamiya Hiroshi which is a great voice actor whom I love a lot. He also voices the main male character in Angel Beats and Arakawa Under the Bridge. 2 Excellent series worth watching and recommended if you seen his one.

The show is really depressing, but funny as well. I guess you could say this is a show about laughing at other people's pains. Almost everyone seems to have problems in this. I guess you could say that it’s like Ren and Stimpy, Ugly American, and Moral Oral all rolled up in one. If you don’t like those shows, then you probably might not like this because even if it’s not really disgusting, it is rather dumb for funs sake. The whole show pretty much is like a long conversation with the branches into other ideas and such, and mostly feels like it's actually critiquingthe Japanese government and culture. They love to play into the mind of the characters so it does get a bit odd and not always in the realistic fashion.


The characters and everything are really a whole play on words, their names meaning pretty much there personalities in Japanese. This does get lost to people who do not know any Japanese and how it’s written. For instance, when you write down Nozomu Itoshiki’s name western style, it becomes the word “zetsubou”, meaning “Despair” hence the name of the show. It goes on with Rin Itoshiki, his younger sister, who when written horizontally becomes “zetsurin” (“unequaled”), Mikoto Itoshiki, his brother, who resembles “zetsumei” (“Death”), and Chiri Kitsu, one of his students, whose name is created from the word “Kitchiri” (“Precisely”) shown when she tries to make everything equal, and also has the kanji for “senrigan” (“Clairvoyance”) and she does show she has psychic principles. The same is done with almost every character although I will not put all of them here because there is a lot. There is no short to characters in this and it’s sometimes hard to keep all of them straight but it seems most of his female students fall in love with him at least in one point.


The show has a lot of the same feelings as Welcome to the NHK, being very abstract and out of control though the animation is rather dark. Many times, I had trouble seeing something because it was so dark. The feel is that of a film being played along with the way the characters are dressed and some of the items around, it makes the show feel older than it is. The only times it really is bright is around Kafuka Fuura, probably to show how optimistic she is all the time but pretty much everything else is either washed out of has a layer of sepia tone layered over. All around the place, there are strange little writings on the walls and in the background that spout little nonsense that means nothing to the actually story line and every time the camera turns back to them, they are different. It’s a interesting little piece. There is a lot of fan service, especially for the American girl and a very strange guy who shows up everywhere in the most random places. It’s normally just a little circle with some guys face in the center and it could be in the background or covering something up. It’s not an anime face but a photo that is placed there which is just really on.


The music is rather odd, and I guess fits with the show though it’s kind of hard to talk about it. I really want to see this dubbed because it's really hard to read all the subs and look for the little tidbits that are in it.

Do you like animes with action, heart wrenching stories, and drama? Well, you're in the wrong place. Sayonara Zetsubou Sensei has none of that. However, that didn't stop this anime from instantly becoming one of my favorites.
Sayonara Zetsubou Sensei starts off with a young girl, Fuura, who is walking to school, only to be stopped by seeing Nozomu Itoshiki, her teacher she finds out later, hanging himself on one of the cherry blossom trees. Fuura saves Itoshiki by yanking him and snapping the rope from the tree. Next thing you know, Itoshiki is telling Fuura, "Are you crazy?! What if I had died!?" And thecraziness continues on from there.


The story basically is low mainly because... well, there really isn't one. Most of SZS is basically a teacher and his students talking about several things (more like flaws) in Japanese culture and society. It may be hard for someone who doesn't know a lot about the Japanese culture, politics, etc, to get all everything that happens in SZS. However, even if you don't know much about Japan, you'll still be laughing at some of the crazy antics going on in Sayonara Zetsubou Sensei.


The art I found was something different. I feel like I haven't seen an art style like this before, which is why I'm giving it a 10. It's something different, and the art style is very cute, not heavily detailed, and just very clean. Plus, some of the silly faces drawn in this make me laugh so hard.


Sound is not something I excel in noticing. I loved the voice actors though, and I feel they did an AMAZING job with the characters.


Characters now. Even though they don't develop at ALL, SZS has some very unique characters, all of which seem to have something wrong with them. Itoshiki is constantly in despair and tries to commit suicide every three minutes, all of which are terrible failures. What makes it even worse for him is that even his name spelled horizontally in Kanji even spells out 'despair'. Fuura is practically the opposite of Itoshiki. Even when Itoshiki is hanging himself, Fuura looks at it as making himself taller. Chiri, another one of Itoshiki's students, is practically the female Death the Kid. No wait, scratch that, Chiri is more OCD than Death the Kid. Her hair is perfectly parted, her socks are always up, even her sleep schedule is perfect. See what I mean with all the characters having something wrong with them?


Overall, I loved Sayonara Zetsubou Sensei. I think people that are fans of Hetalia might call this a bit similar with the undeveloping characters and the lack of storyline. However, this is not at all similar. It's very different actually. Watch it and you'll see it's different~

This review generally relates to the whole Sayonara Zetsubou Sensei franchise since all seasons are extremely similar in their nature.
Sayonara Zetsubou Sensei (or SZS), a show based on satirical manga by Kumeta Kouji, has the right to be called one of the most unique and mentionable representatives of "black comedy" genre in anime. It involves different types of humour and has a very atypical execution. Basically there's no deep meaning and phylosophical subtext in Sayonara Zetsubou Sensei, but it doesn't feel empty or pointless. Due to its great satirical content the show even might cause you to change your mind about some things in yourlife you never paid much attention to. 


Story  (6)

Basically SZS is an episodic sketch comedy, so don't expect to find there any linear storyline - only few minor changes might be noticed throughout episodes. But that doesn't mean this show is boring or too repetitive. All the characters get through a plenty of miscellaneous situations, and setting changes drastically from episode to episode ranging from slice-of-life stories to weird surreal tales. 


Art (6)

In terms of art SZS follows the original manga, so artwork is very sketchy and atypical for anime. Outlines and colouring are kinda rough, and the show is relatively poorly animated, mostly being static. Overall the art might look quite unappealing. However, hard to disagree the show has very unique visual style with its own recognizable features which helps to feel the originality of the show. Furthermore, sometimes visual style changes completely, parodying anime of 80's, famous paintings and so on. Spectacular!


Characters (9)

After gradual introduction of all characters it appears that they are quite numerous, and none of them (except the lead character, Itoshiki Nozomu aka Mr. Despair) is more important for the show than others. Everyone has peculiar manners, behaviour, catch phrases; each character seems very different, but altogether they make up an unexplainable harmony which creates a solid groundwork for jokes and keeps you attached to the cast. The most mentionable character and the main source of dark satiric humour is Zetsubou Sensei himself, or Itoshiki Nozomu. He's a 100% pessimist constantly complaining about flaws of modern society and often attempting suicide, but failing at that every time. I guess there's no need to say how atypical and hilarious he is.


Sound (8)

All of the music is written by Hasegawa Tomoki known for composing background soundtracks for anime show Nana. OST for SZS is very memorable and just beautiful. The only reproach here - a plenty of tracks sound overly dramatic and don't actually fit comical nature of the show. Voicing is done well with no apparent flaws. Every characters' voice fits his/her nature excellently, hard to imagine something more suitable.


Enjoyment (9)

The primary goal of the show it to entertain the viewer and make him laugh. And this is where SZS truly succeeds. 

So, do you like cultural references? Dark humour? Or social satire? Subtle intellectual humour, maybe? In any of these cases, SZS has something to offer. The show features numerous parodies and mockery, dark satire, intellectual jokes and even self-irony (which I personally consider one the best types of humour). Yet you'd better keep in mind that SZS is not a brainless comedy that can be easily understood by anyone on  instant. SZS makes you analyze information, read a lot of on-screen text and follow quite fluent dialogues - therefore marathoning it most likely wouldn't be a great idea.  SZS can be fully understood only in case you're familiar with  notable examples of both western and japanese culture, and furthermore you'd better have some anime watching experience and (desirably) basic knowledge of Japanese. Otherwise don't be surprised if the anime looks like a random nonsense for you. 


Overall

Put in short, here are strong and weak points of the show.

Pros:

+ diverse humour

+ lots of parodies and cultural references

+ likeable characters 

+ unique visual style

+ great music, sound and voicing


Cons:

- unappealing animation

- lack of storyline and any development

- fanservice and harem elements (though both of them are ironic)

- requires basic knowledge of japanese culture and decent anime watching experience

- quite difficult to get drawn into


Considering all its flaws and trying to judge objectively, this show deserves a score of 7 (good). However, that doesn't mean SZS is just "good" if you love dark humour, cultural references and unusual execution. In that case Sayonara Zetsubou Sensei might easily become one of the most amusing, memorable and complex comedies you've ever encountered. 


Are you ready to be thrown into DESPAIR?

Take one terminally depressed, suicidal adult. Make him the teacher of a class full of psychologically disturbed students, each one of them embodying a mental disorder or extreme character archetype. Add to the mix a great helping of dark humour and social insights, and it can easily be said that Sayonara Zetsubou Sensei is a must see for anyone itching for a comedy series with a side of philosophy and satire.
There is no plot to follow, characters don’t develop beyond their stereotypes, and often time’s logic is completely thrown out the window. However, it still manages to be the smartest comedy-anime I’ve ever seen. Theideas being given are interesting, and deal with basic truths about society and human behavior. It’s not afraid to delve in taboo subjects either, ranging from jokes about shut-ins, stalkers, drug users, and suicide. Not even the audience is off limits, with some of the jokes taking pot-shots on anime fans and the overly moe-fanatical anime industry. After a while, the basic formula of the show becomes apparent, and it usually it goes like this: One concept is brought forth, built upon, played with by the various wacked out students, and becomes more and more ridiculous. However, with the myriad of unique topics being presented, the comedy remains to feel fresh. Most of the humor is quite universal, although there are jokes that will go over most American viewer’s heads, with jokes and about Japanese celebrities, kanji puns, or Japanese politics. Thankfully these Japan-centric jokes are never the focus of the punchlines, so viewers shouldn’t feel out of place.



As for the characters, although their personalities are paper-thin archetypes, all of them are incredibly enjoyable. Each character adds a lot to the parodies and jokes because of their own different, messed up perspectives. Needless to say, there’s barely any character development (with the exception of one particular student who’s hinted at being quite darker than what she seems…), however most viewers will find their favorite instantly based upon their own individual tendencies. Itoshiki Nozomu (or Mr. Despair) is by far the star of the show, whose suicidal antics and cynical views remain the focus of most of the episodes. One would think that so much negativety would become grating, but the show manages to pull it off quite well. There aren’t many series where the lead character extends an offer to another to commit suicide with him, and have it come off as being endearing rather than evil.

Photobucket


As for the animation, for the most part it’s pretty simplistic, although there are some scenes that are incredibly well animated. What really makes this series feel different are the rapidly varying art styles and angles, which keeps the viewer very much visually stimulated. There’s also a hell of a lot of comedic detail packed into the backgrounds, with the numerous random quips written on the blackboards, or lists of despairs which Nozomu is currently fretting about.

Photobucket


All in all, Sayonara Zetsubou Sensei is a very funny comedy series which shouldn’t be missed by anyone who likes dark humor, as well as people who want a smart comedy packed with both philosophy and satire. With most anime comedies either being redundant “slice of life” shows or moe-centric “watching cute girls do cute things”, Sayonara Zetsubou Sensei is a welcome reprieve.

Sayonara Zetsubou Sensei is a dark comedy anime about a pessimistic, suicidal high-school teacher who teaches a bunch of mentally broken girls about how horrible and negative the world is. One student has serve O.C.D., another one is a hikikomori, one has a guilt complex, and one is an extreme optimist, who sincerely believes that there's literally nothing in the world that is negative; she's the polar opposite of Zetsubou-Sensei. Nozomu Itoshiki is the Zetsubou-Sensei. If you put the first two characters of his name too close together, his name says, "Zetsubou," which means, "Despair."
Episode formula:
1.) Zetsubou-Sensei conveys a statement about a negative aspect ofsociety, and on some occasions, the world.


2.) He then gives examples to further prove his point. Most of the time, the show uses metaphorical commentary to get it through the viewer.


3.) His students come out of nowhere, and give their opinion on the subject.


4.) Kafuka Fuura (The extremely optimistic student I mentioned) counters said statement that Zetsubou-Sensei said, and mentions the positive side of the subject.


5.) All of this is going on while the show makes cultural references (Specifically Japanese references), on rare occasions, foreign culture, anime, manga, video games, and even classical literature.


Season one in probably the weakest of the three seasons. Season one focuses more on introducing characters. Most of the appeal is the wacky yet dark humor the series has, and season one doesn't go to the extreme like the other two seasons do. As a whole, the entire series is amazing and hilarious, depending on your sense of humor.

I LOVE SAYONARA, ZETSUBOU-SENSEI!
First of all, even though it takes the smallest situations in the most dramatic way possible, it's very humorous. I think with the support of all the interesting characters the story flows very well. What I also like is that the story doesn't just stick to one plot. I think for this anime that would be bad. 
Second, I love all of the charaters and their voices! They match perfectly. I am a big Kamiya Hiroshi fan so when I first heard Itoshiki Nozomu I was hugging everything around me very tightly. I think the voice actor of Maria is excellent too.\n\n
Third, I absolutely love all of the references it makes. For example, when taking a tour of Harumi Fujiyoshi, there were 00 references everywhere. They even had some members of Vocaloid come in!\n\n
Overall, if you're looking for obscure humor I highly recommend this. It's hilarious and it teaches you a thing or two about society... and despair.

Watching this series felt like I had found a diamond in the rough. It was hard as hell to find a live torrent of this in .mkv and decent resolution but my effort was well worth it.
This show is a breath of fresh air if you have been watching a lot of the more popular animes such as myself. Now what to say about this?
I guess the best way to describe what to expect is this, the humorous events that occur are really only half of this show, the other half is actually watching it. I have never seen an anime that requires so muchattention visually. I found myself constantly pausing to try to catch stuff that was happening in the backround, or written on papers/blackboards/signs, ect... Its not really NECESSARY but if your OCD like me you will want to know.\n\n
This is a really well crafted anime, which means that everything just sort of fits together perfectly, and that mixed with its witty and fresh humor, and artistic direction make this anime one I endorse as a must see!\n\n
all that being said...\n
...WRITING THIS REVIEW HAS LEFT ME IN DISPAIR!\n
there are sure to be people who don't find this review helpful, soon users from all over the internet will be watching this show and left disappointed because they think I over-hyped it. My name will become synonymous with bad anime! [gets noose]....

This will be a challenge since this is definitely the most ORIGINAL anime I have ever seen. It is hard to describe. Watching it is truly a unique experience. I screamed a lot while watching it out of hilarity and fear. This combination of feelings is delightfully painful and awkward. 
The story is not cut and dry - it's random and not really about a plot as much as it is about well, randomness. There are tons of interludes and filler parts that will confuse you but are creative and enjoyable. Sometimes they're scary just because they're invasive to what your mind predicts.
TONS of culturereferences. They can be funny even if you don't get them because they're presented in such an odd way.

It's almost a parody anime because you can tell it knows it's random and it knows it's poking fun.  


I really loved the art - it was truly original. At times it was beautiful, at times just interesting, and even disturbing but in a good way. I think some may be lost at the unpredictability of it but if it interests you at all, you won't be disappointed.

The people in charge of the anime sure love to have cameos. Prepare for that, as it is a very common occurrence.


The music was also interesting. It's funny in an awkward way, like "What is this?" and it's great because it fits the whole series.


The characters are amazing. Itoshiki-sensei is very true to himself and so hilariously tragic, it's easy to like him but it can be hard to decide whether or not you actually feel sorry for him. The issues the characters face are relatable but also outrageous - exaggerated, if you will. The flaws of the characters can be shocking but are also not too foreign.

Simply put, it makes one realize that they themselves are also a creep of some sort.


There's lots of fanservice - male-targeted. This bothered me a little bit, but it doesn't take away from the story.


Overall, I'd describe it as a satirical crackfest that's one of a kind and truly enjoyable for those open to it. I recommend it to almost anyone.

Yes the characters are one note and defined by their "gimmicks", that is the joke, and I for one think it works very well. 
Sayonara Zetsubou Sensei is a parody anime. What it is parodying is the average harem, for instance Da Capo or Absolute Duo. For the record, I hate absolute duo. Why? Because I see it as the most average of average harems. There is nothing unique. This is exactly why Sayonara Zetsubou Sensei is so hilarious to me. Take Julie from AD, for instance. She is the token kuudere character. We don't know much about her other than that she is akuudere and she comes from some place in the north. We also know what her boobs look like because fanservice is more important than character development...? Oh dear. Then, let's take Kafuka from SZS. She is hilariously cheerful. Her only personality trait is that she is cheerful. It works because Zetsubou Sensei is so depressed. The two extremes work remarkably well! For instance, in episode one, he is trying to hang himself. Kafuka comes along and decides that he is simply trying to make himself taller. Just like her father did on frequent occasions.


Nuff said.

Definitely not what I expected while watching. More sexual...visualizations(?) then anticipated originally. Over all I think I can say I liked this. There's a lot of social criticism not only of basic things like politics and economics, but they even go so far as to make fun of things like Yaoi/Yuri and the anime and manga industries. The story doesn't revolve quite as much around Sensei as I thought it would, and there were certain episodes that were rather pointless (though I guess in essence the whole anime was really pointless) such as the arranged marriage episode. 
Other then that, I would recommend this animeonly to people with quirky, twisted senses of humor and don't mind a little visualized girl on girl action from time to time. Awesome first opening theme.

Sayonara Zetsubou Sensei (or So Long, Mr. Despair) is a comedic anime about a depressed high school teacher done by SHAFT and directed by Akiyuki Shinbo. I generally don't like comedy anime because they're usually either moe or spastic Excel Saga-type shows. Zetsubou Sensei is different though because most of the humor comes from the show being so strange. They constantly cut to random scenes that are there only to act as gags, experimental animation styles are used at times, and nonsensical sections are interjected for no reason at all. The anime is soo weird and so rooted in Japanese culture that it will neverget licensed. It's all been fansubbed so far, so you can watch this odd series subbed. You could also check out the manga, but without the voice acting and decent character designs, much of the weirdness and humor has been removed.

Kafuka Fuura a cheerful and happy girl who always looks on the positives of life is an average high school girl who happens to be on her way to school. On her travels she finds and man attempting to hang himself.
After seemingly stopping the attention seeking teacher that sets in motion the chain of unrelated events and the daily life of our absurdest teacher Zetsubo Sensei.
I loved watching Welcome to the NHK which was had elements of serious elements of social and mental defects. Such as depression, shut-in's, suicide cults and more. I like it when shows add in elements of serious issuesof society and make it into something light hearted. I was hoping this show would be the same... well let’s explore that.




Story:




Now i wouldn't necessarily say that this series has an overarching story. Essentially the series is just showing us the wacky and random events in the daily life of a depressed teacher and his students. That’s not necessarily a bad thing and since it is a comedy it relies more on its strong characters and comedic moments which are there to see. However the jokes used in Zetsubo Sensei can be hit or miss. Some episodes you can get a good laugh and other times it can be meh. The show does re-use some jokes and i does get repetitive. This series also tends to have sexual references without making it obvious such as a teacher bathing with her student and pleasure through pain or S&M.




Art:




The art is very strange and fascinating. The character designs are very 2D. There are moments when the animation is very nice to look at because of the unusual sight. The opening is also a strange and creepy thing to watch, but its so different that I couldn't skip it for the life of me. Another thing that had me thinking was that in each episode it had a picture of what i presumed to be the creator's face. It was strange but i didn't mind.




Sound:




To be perfectly honest I didn't really notice the soundtrack for most parts. I may have to have another listen to the soundtrack. The opening was really good and the closing had a spooky can of theme. All in all it’s ok.




Characters:


We follow what i assume to be our protagonist Nozomu Itoshiki a depressed teacher who just can't to seem to see anything in a positive light. His character never really develops as we still see the same old teacher refusing to change hos beliefs and ideals. He isn't exactly a great teacher or role model as he is constantly berating his students and diminishes their hopes and dreams with the iron fist of reality. 


The only other character who plays equally as big role is Kafuka Fu'ura. She is the happy and super positive heroine of the series. She stops Nozomu from killing himself and then proceeds to befriend him. The relationship between the two seems non-existent but the two do show a mutual interest in each other and seeing as this is only the first season who knows what else could happen. 


Final Verdict:


While i can praise the show for being something quite different and a series aimed more at my tastes Sayonara Zetsubo Sensei is an above average show that can be a hit or miss. As for its humour it can also be a hit or miss. The series will feel longer than it should if it drags out and repeats it dark jokes. Overall i give this show a 7 out of 10 and a recommendation to at least try the first three episodes. If its not for you then you'll know straight off the bat 


Thanks for reading guys. Any comments are welcome and until then. Have a nice day!
